comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a reverse (aft?, stern?) view of the 'Royal Art[hur]', unidentified. Is it Sutherland Dock on Cockatoo Island? Should be relatively easy to get a date via Trove. [edited] Now also on Flickr - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6241480023/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Numerous other photographs available, and also a couple of paintings by Julian Rossi Ashton - (Australian War Memorial)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Trove shows several times the 'Royal Arthur' was at Sutherland Dock - August 1898 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14158207?searchTerm=roya... October 1898 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14152336?searchTerm=roya... May 1899 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14213815?searchTerm=roya... April 1900 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14304537?searchTerm=roya... Hmm?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64403351@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks for all this extra information; we've updated the date from "No date" to "c.1900".

AB

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: Its definitely Sutherland Dock as is the one from beachcomberaustralia and well before WWI from the lack of buildings to the left of the ship.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Same dock, earlier photo by Henry King - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2495798031/] Zoom right in for amazing detail - from.ph/30728

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I wonder if these photos of the Sutherland Dock are perhaps not a record of the ships, but a record of the Public Works Department facility and its capabilities, especially the three photos of the HMS Torch, Ringdove, and Goldfinch (December 1898 via Trove) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and very slightly different (see the sailor swabbing) investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... The Sutherland Dock was named after John Sutherland, the Secretary for Public Works, but was originally going to be called Carrington Dock after the then Governor. See this excellent article with full details of how it works and illustrations at the time of opening - 'Town and Country Journal' 14/6/1890 p.10 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71112786 . Zoomable illustrations p.32, 33 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/5233157 .

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just for interest here's a 1904 T&CJ article on HMS Euryalus nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71514639 ; and a 1906 T&CJ article on HMS Powerful - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5726968 ...both in the Sutherland Dock

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: ...and a fantastic 1899 T&CJ article on HMS Royal Arthur (not in the Sutherland Dock) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71332666

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a few 1898 Sydney Mail pics of HMS Royal Arthur in the Sutherland Dock - news.google.com/newspapers?id=p1ZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=npUDA... - per the accompanying blurb, these Sydney Mail pics would appear to have been taken in October 1898...though for all we know the pics might have been taken on the earlier visit...Whatever the case, the SM pic of the bow (at least) appears to have been taken during the same docking as this SRNSW pic (above)...the tug/barge looks to be in the same location...from what I can make out the supporting beams are in the same locations...though a few planks and ladders have been shifted around...all up it appears that this SRNSW pic (above) dates from either August or October 1898. The SM pics of the stern also appear to have been taken during the same docking as the SRNSW pics of the stern...it's difficult to tell...but the beam/plank placed on ladders at the front of the rudder appears to be in the same position...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: ! This October 1898 T&CJ pic of the bow is an even better match...looks like the same pic - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71319210 ...unless the SM and T&CJ both used pics from HMS Royal Arthur's August 1898 docking, I'd say we're looking at October 1898.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's a 1902 Sydney Mail pictorial on HMS Royal Arthur - news.google.com/newspapers?id=N21VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Y5UDA...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] The October 1898 photo is a great match except the fellow on the gangway has moved, and the fellow on the bow has gone! I vote for October 1898!

comment.author: 79583367@N02
comment._content: And I thought bulbous bows were a new invention !

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79583367@N02] I think the reinforced pointy bit was used for ramming other ships broadside, a tactic going right back to the Ancient Greeks and Phoenicians.  See also HMS TORCH (in Fitzroy Dock) -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3055005210/]
